message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is involved in glycolysis and is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, which is a feed-forward activator. Glucose-6-phosphate inhibits pyruvate kinase. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and alanine are not involved in the regulation of pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is a key enzyme in glycolysis, and fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is a positive allosteric regulator of pyruvate kinase. This means that fructose-1,6-bisphosphate binds to the enzyme and increases its activity, enhancing the conversion of glucose to pyruvate. Glucose-6-phosphate can inhibit pyruvate kinase, while glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and alanine do not have a direct regulatory effect on the enzyme.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is involved in the regulation of glycolysis and is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. The other options are not known to activate pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. This is an example of feed-forward regulation because fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is a substrate of an earlier step in glycolysis and its accumulation signals that the pathway is active and requires more pyruvate kinase activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is a regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, and fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is an activator of pyruvate kinase. Glucose-6-phosphate is a negative regulator of the enzyme, while glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and alanine are not involved in the regulation of pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase functions in glycolysis and is involved in feed-forward regulation, which means that the reaction catalyzed by pyruvate kinase is regulated by the product of a previous reaction. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is the activator for pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis and is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Glucose-6-phosphate inhibits pyruvate kinase, while glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and alanine are not involved in the regulation of pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate in a process called feed-forward regulation. Glucose-6-phosphate inhibits pyruvate kinase. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and alanine are not involved in the regulation of pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is involved in the regulation of glycolysis, particularly in the conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to pyruvate. Therefore, the metabolite that activates pyruvate kinase is fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Glucose-6-phosphate is an early intermediate in glycolysis, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is an intermediate in the conversion of glucose to pyruvate, and alanine is a product of glucose metabolism through alanine transamination. None of these directly activate pyruvate kinase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pyruvate kinase is involved in glycolysis and is activated by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate, which is an intermediate in the same pathway. The other metabolites listed, glucose-6-phosphate, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, and alanine, are all intermediates in glycolysis but do not directly activate pyruvate kinase.
